question: Sucrose is dextrorotatory but after hydrolysis the mixture show laevorotation, this is because of
choices: Laevorotation of fructose is more than dextrorotation of glucose.
Laevorotation of glucose is more than dextrorotation of fructose.
explanation: Hydrolysis of sucrose (dextrorotatory, <katex>$+66.5^{\circ}$</katex>) gives D-(+)-glucose (<katex>$+52.5^{\circ}$</katex>) and D-(-)-fructose (<katex>$-92.4^{\circ}$</katex>).

Since the magnitude of laevorotation of fructose (<katex>$-92.4^{\circ}$</katex>) is greater than the dextrorotation of glucose (<katex>$+52.5^{\circ}$</katex>), the resulting mixture is laevorotatory.
This product is known as Invert Sugar.
